content: The "Belarus Democracy Reauthorization Act of 2006" cites violations of human rights and democratic principles by the Government of Belarus, particularly in the flawed 2006 presidential elections. The regime of Aleksandr Lukashenka in Belarus has maintained power through illegal means, including orchestrating an unconstitutional referendum and suppressing political opposition. The government has also failed to address cases of disappeared opposition figures and journalists, raising concerns about human rights violations and lack of political competition in the country. The Lukashenka regime in Belarus has been linked to disappearances of opposition figures and journalists. Political activists face imprisonment and harassment for their activities, especially after the 2006 presidential elections. The government controls the information space, targeting independent media and suppressing freedom of speech. The Lukashenka regime in Belarus has perpetuated a climate of fear by cracking down on civil society, harassing minority religious communities, and silencing dissent through threats and intimidation. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is being amended to address these issues. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is being amended to call for the release of political prisoners, support democracy and human rights in Belarus, preserve the country's independence, promote democratic movements, and reject the results of flawed elections. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is being amended to support democracy, human rights, and independence in Belarus, reject flawed election results, and promote integration into the European community of democracies. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is being amended to support democracy, human rights, and independence in Belarus by expanding independent media and promoting a democratic political culture and civil society. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is being amended to support democracy, human rights, and independence in Belarus by enhancing independent media, civil society, human rights defenders, democratic political parties, and electoral processes. Authorization of appropriations is also updated for 2007 and 2008. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is amended to include radio and television broadcasting to Belarus, updating authorization of appropriations for 2007 and 2008. Additionally, sanctions against the government of Belarus are addressed. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is amended to include sanctions against the government of Belarus until specific conditions are met, including the release of jailed individuals based on political or religious beliefs and the withdrawal of politically motivated legal charges against opposition activists and journalists. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 calls for the release of jailed individuals based on political or religious beliefs, withdrawal of politically motivated charges against opposition activists and journalists, accountability for disappearances of opposition leaders and journalists, cessation of harassment against independent media and political opposition, prosecution of government officials responsible for fraudulent elections and embezzlement of state assets. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 demands accountability for fraudulent elections and embezzlement of state assets by the Government of Belarus, including denial of entry into the United States for senior leadership involved in such activities. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 prohibits individuals who are immediate family members of inadmissible persons or who benefit financially from actions undermining democracy in Belarus. It also restricts US government financing and Trade and Development Agency funds for Belarus, except for humanitarian goods and specific products. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 restricts US government financing and Trade and Development Agency funds for Belarus, except for humanitarian goods and specific products. Congress also urges blocking assets and financial assistance to the Government of Belarus, except for loans serving humanitarian needs. The President should block all property and interests in property owned by the Government of Belarus or closely linked individuals that undermine democratic institutions in Belarus. This includes assets in the United States or controlled by US financial institutions. The President should block property and interests owned by the Government of Belarus or closely linked individuals. Prohibited activities include payments to the Government of Belarus or its senior leadership, and the export of goods to entities controlled by the government. The President should block property and interests owned by the Government of Belarus or closely linked individuals, including any contracts supporting government operations. Expenses for blocking property should be charged to the owners or operators. Exceptions include assistance authorized under specific sections of the Act. The President can block property and interests of the Government of Belarus or closely linked individuals, with expenses charged to owners or operators. Exceptions include authorized assistance and humanitarian aid to Belarus. Violations will be subject to penalties under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Definitions include 'air carrier' and 'United States person'. SEC. 7. MULTILATERAL COOPERATION. Amends Section 7 of the Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 to enhance support for comprehensive cooperation. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. Amends Section 9(3) to include additional individuals in the definition. In subparagraph (B), amends the text to include individuals engaged in public corruption in Belarus.
